metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: XML RSS
With RSS it is possible to distribute up-to-date web content from one web site to thousands of other web sites around the world.
content.html: With RSS it is possible to distribute up-to-date web content from one web site to thousands of other web sites around the world.

content.text: RSS allows fast browsing for news and updates.
content.html: RSS allows fast browsing for news and updates.

content.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>

<rss version="2.0">


<channel>


<title>W3Schools Home Page</title>


<link>https://www.w3schools.com</link>


<description>Free web building tutorials</description>


<item>


<title>RSS Tutorial</title>


<link>https://www.w3schools.com/xml/xml_rss.asp</link>


<description>New RSS tutorial on W3Schools</description>


</item>


<item>


<title>XML Tutorial</title>


<link>https://www.w3schools.com/xml</link>


<description>New XML tutorial on W3Schools</description>


</item>

</channel>


</rss>
content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>
<rss version="2.0">

<channel>
  <title>W3Schools Home Page</title>
  <link>https://www.w3schools.com</link>
  <description>Free web building tutorials</description>
  <item>
    <title>RSS Tutorial</title>
    <link>https://www.w3schools.com/xml/xml_rss.asp</link>
    <description>New RSS tutorial on W3Schools</description>
  </item>
  <item>
    <title>XML Tutorial</title>
    <link>https://www.w3schools.com/xml</link>
    <description>New XML tutorial on W3Schools</description>
  </item>
</channel>

</rss>

content.text: What is RSS?
Why use RSS?
RSS was designed to show selected data.
content.html: RSS was designed to show selected data.

content.text: Without RSS, users will have to check your site daily for new updates. This may be too time-consuming for many users. With an RSS feed (RSS is often called a News feed or RSS feed) they can check your site faster using an RSS aggregator (a site or program that gathers and sorts out RSS feeds).
content.html: Without RSS, users will have to check your site daily for new updates. This may be too time-consuming for many users. With an RSS feed (RSS is often called a News feed or RSS feed) they can check your site faster using an RSS aggregator (a site or program that gathers and sorts out RSS feeds).

content.text: Since RSS data is small and fast-loading, it can easily be used with services like cell phones or PDA's.
content.html: Since RSS data is small and fast-loading, it can easily be used with services like cell phones or PDA's.

content.text: Web-rings with similar information can easily share data on their web sites to make them better and more useful.
content.html: Web-rings with similar information can easily share data on their web sites to make them better and more useful.

content.text: Who Should use RSS?
Webmasters who seldom update their web sites do not need RSS!
content.html: Webmasters who seldom update their web sites do not need RSS!

content.text: RSS is useful for web sites that are updated frequently, like:
content.html: RSS is useful for web sites that are updated frequently, like:

content.text: Benefits of RSS
Here are some benefits of using RSS:
content.html: Here are some benefits of using RSS:

content.text: Choose your news With RSS you can choose to view the news you want, the news that interest you and are relevant to your work.
content.html:
Choose your news
With RSS you can choose to view the news you want, the news that interest you and are relevant to your work.

content.text: Remove unwanted information With RSS you can (finally) separate wanted information from unwanted information (spam)!
content.html:
Remove unwanted information
With RSS you can (finally) separate wanted information from unwanted information (spam)!

content.text: Increase your site traffic With RSS you can create your own news channel, and publish it to the Internet!
content.html:
Increase your site traffic
With RSS you can create your own news channel, and publish it to the Internet!

content.text: The History of RSS
RSS 1.0 is the only version that was developed using the W3C RDF (Resource Description Framework) standard.
content.html: RSS 1.0 is the only version that was developed using the W3C RDF (Resource Description Framework) standard.

content.text: The idea behind RDF was to help create a Semantic Web. However, this does not matter too much for ordinary users, but by using web standards it will be easier for persons and applications to exchange data.
content.html: The idea behind RDF was to help create a Semantic Web. However, this does not matter too much for ordinary users, but by using web standards it will be easier for persons and applications to exchange data.

content.text: What RSS Version Should I Use?
RSS 0.91 and RSS 2.0 are easier to understand than RSS 1.0. Our tutorial is based on RSS 2.0.
content.html: RSS 0.91 and RSS 2.0 are easier to understand than RSS 1.0. Our tutorial is based on RSS 2.0.

content.text: The syntax rules of RSS 2.0 are very simple and very strict.
content.html: The syntax rules of RSS 2.0 are very simple and very strict.

content.text: Is RSS a Web Standard?
There is no official standard for RSS.
content.html: There is no official standard for RSS.

content.text: How RSS Works
RSS is used to share content between websites.
content.html: RSS is used to share content between websites.

content.text: With RSS, you register your content with companies called aggregators.
content.html: With RSS, you register your content with companies called aggregators.

content.text: So, to be a part of it: First, create an RSS document and save it with an .xml extension. Then, upload the file to your website. Next, register with an RSS aggregator. Each day the aggregator searches the registered websites for RSS documents, verifies the link, and displays information about the feed so clients can link to documents that interests them.
content.html: So, to be a part of it: First, create an RSS document and save it with an .xml extension. Then, upload the file to your website. Next, register with an RSS aggregator. Each day the aggregator searches the registered websites for RSS documents, verifies the link, and displays information about the feed so clients can link to documents that interests them.

content.text: Tip: Read our RSS Publishing chapter to view free RSS aggregation services.
content.html: Tip: Read our RSS Publishing chapter to view free RSS aggregation services.

content.text: RSS Example
RSS documents use a self-describing and simple syntax.
content.html: RSS documents use a self-describing and simple syntax.

content.text: Here is a simple RSS document:
content.html: Here is a simple RSS document:

content.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>

<rss version="2.0">


<channel>


<title>W3Schools Home Page</title>


<link>https://www.w3schools.com</link>


<description>Free web building tutorials</description>


<item>


<title>RSS Tutorial</title>


<link>https://www.w3schools.com/xml/xml_rss.asp</link>


<description>New RSS tutorial on W3Schools</description>


</item>


<item>


<title>XML Tutorial</title>


<link>https://www.w3schools.com/xml</link>


<description>New XML tutorial on W3Schools</description>


</item>

</channel>


</rss>
content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>
<rss version="2.0">

<channel>
  <title>W3Schools Home Page</title>
  <link>https://www.w3schools.com</link>
  <description>Free web building tutorials</description>
  <item>
    <title>RSS Tutorial</title>
    <link>https://www.w3schools.com/xml/xml_rss.asp</link>
    <description>New RSS tutorial on W3Schools</description>
  </item>
  <item>
    <title>XML Tutorial</title>
    <link>https://www.w3schools.com/xml</link>
    <description>New XML tutorial on W3Schools</description>
  </item>
</channel>

</rss>

content.text: The first line in the document - the XML declaration - defines the XML version and the character encoding used in the document. In this case the document conforms to the 1.0 specification of XML and uses the UTF-8 character set.
content.html: The first line in the document - the XML declaration - defines the XML version and the character encoding used in the document. In this case the document conforms to the 1.0 specification of XML and uses the UTF-8 character set.

content.text: The next line is the RSS declaration which identifies that this is an RSS document (in this case, RSS version 2.0).
content.html: The next line is the RSS declaration which identifies that this is an RSS document (in this case, RSS version 2.0).

content.text: The next line contains the <channel> element. This element is used to describe the RSS feed.
content.html: The next line contains the <channel> element. This element is used to describe the RSS feed.

content.text: The <channel> element has three required child elements:
content.html: The <channel> element has three required child elements:

content.text: Each <channel> element can have one or more <item> elements.
content.html: Each <channel> element can have one or more <item> elements.

content.text: Each <item> element defines an article or "story" in the RSS feed.
content.html: Each <item> element defines an article or "story" in the RSS feed.

content.text: The <item> element has three required child elements:
content.html: The <item> element has three required child elements:

content.text: Finally, the two last lines close the <channel> and <rss> elements.
content.html: Finally, the two last lines close the <channel> and <rss> elements.

content.text: Comments in RSS
The syntax for writing comments in RSS is similar to that of HTML:
content.html: The syntax for writing comments in RSS is similar to that of HTML:

content.code_html: <!-- This is an RSS comment -->

content.text: RSS is Written in XML
Because RSS is XML, keep in mind that:
content.html: Because RSS is XML, keep in mind that:

content.text: The RSS <channel> Element
The RSS <channel> element describes the RSS feed.
content.html: The RSS <channel> element describes the RSS feed.

content.text: Look at the following RSS document:
content.html: Look at the following RSS document:

content.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>

<rss version="2.0">


<channel>


<title>W3Schools Home Page</title>


<link>https://www.w3schools.com</link>


<description>Free web building tutorials</description>


<item>


<title>RSS Tutorial</title>


<link>https://www.w3schools.com/xml/xml_rss.asp</link>


<description>New RSS tutorial on W3Schools</description>


</item>

</channel>


</rss>
content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>
<rss version="2.0">

<channel>
  <title>W3Schools Home Page</title>
  <link>https://www.w3schools.com</link>
  <description>Free web building tutorials</description>
  <item>
    <title>RSS Tutorial</title>
    <link>https://www.w3schools.com/xml/xml_rss.asp</link>
    <description>New RSS tutorial on W3Schools</description>
  </item>
</channel>

</rss>

content.text: As mentioned before, the <channel> element describes the RSS feed, and has three required child elements:
content.html: As mentioned before, the <channel> element describes the RSS feed, and has three required child elements:

content.text: The <channel> element usually contains one or more <item> elements. Each <item> element defines an article or "story" in the RSS feed.
content.html: The <channel> element usually contains one or more <item> elements. Each <item> element defines an article or "story" in the RSS feed.

content.text: Furthermore, there are several optional child elements of <channel>. We will explain the most important ones below.
content.html: Furthermore, there are several optional child elements of <channel>. We will explain the most important ones below.

content.text: The <category> Element
The <category> child element is used to specify a category for your feed.
content.html: The <category> child element is used to specify a category for your feed.

content.text: The <category> element makes it possible for RSS aggregators to group sites based on category.
content.html: The <category> element makes it possible for RSS aggregators to group sites based on category.

content.text: The category for the RSS document above could be:
content.html: The category for the RSS document above could be:

content.code_html: <category>Web development</category>

content.text: The <copyright> Element
The <copyright> child element notifies about copyrighted material.
content.html: The <copyright> child element notifies about copyrighted material.

content.text: The copyright for the RSS document above could be:
content.html: The copyright for the RSS document above could be:

content.code: <copyright>2006 Refsnes Data as. All rights reserved.</copyright>
content.code_html: <copyright>2006 Refsnes Data as. All rights reserved.</copyright>

content.text: The <image> Element
The <image> child element allows an image to be displayed when aggregators present a feed.
content.html: The <image> child element allows an image to be displayed when aggregators present a feed.

content.text: The <image> element has three required child elements:
content.html: The <image> element has three required child elements:

content.text: The image for the RSS document above could be:
content.html: The image for the RSS document above could be:

content.code_html:
<image>
  <url>https://www.w3schools.com/images/logo.gif</url>
  <title>W3Schools.com</title>
  <link>https://www.w3schools.com</link>
</image>

content.text: The <language> Element
The <language> child element is used to specify the language used to write your document.
content.html: The <language> child element is used to specify the language used to write your document.

content.text: The <language> element makes it possible for RSS aggregators to group sites based on language.
content.html: The <language> element makes it possible for RSS aggregators to group sites based on language.

content.text: The language for the RSS document above could be:
content.html: The language for the RSS document above could be:

content.code_html: <language>en-us</language>

content.text: The <item> Element
Each <item> element defines an article or "story" in an RSS feed.
content.html: Each <item> element defines an article or "story" in an RSS feed.

content.text: Look at the following RSS document:
content.html: Look at the following RSS document:

content.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>

<rss version="2.0">


<channel>


<title>W3Schools Home Page</title>


<link>https://www.w3schools.com</link>


<description>Free web building tutorials</description>


<item>


<title>RSS Tutorial</title>


<link>https://www.w3schools.com/xml/xml_rss.asp</link>


<description>New RSS tutorial on W3Schools</description>


</item>

</channel>


</rss>
content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>
<rss version="2.0">

<channel>
  <title>W3Schools Home Page</title>
  <link>https://www.w3schools.com</link>
  <description>Free web building tutorials</description>
  <item>
    <title>RSS Tutorial</title>
    <link>https://www.w3schools.com/xml/xml_rss.asp</link>
    <description>New RSS tutorial on W3Schools</description>
  </item>
</channel>

</rss>

content.text: As mentioned before, each <item> element defines an article or "story" in the RSS feed.
content.html: As mentioned before, each <item> element defines an article or "story" in the RSS feed.

content.text: The <item> element has three required child elements:
content.html: The <item> element has three required child elements:

content.text: Furthermore, there are several optional child elements of <item>. We will explain the most important ones below.
content.html: Furthermore, there are several optional child elements of <item>. We will explain the most important ones below.

content.text: The <author> Element
The <author> child element is used to specify the e-mail address of the author of an item.
content.html: The <author> child element is used to specify the e-mail address of the author of an item.

content.text: Note: To prevent spam e-mails, some developers do not include the <author> element.
content.html: Note: To prevent spam e-mails, some developers do not include the <author> element.

content.text: The author of the item in the RSS document above could be:
content.html: The author of the item in the RSS document above could be:

content.code_html: <author>hege@refsnesdata.no</author>

content.text: The <comments> Element
The <comments> child element allows an item to link to comments about that item.
content.html: The <comments> child element allows an item to link to comments about that item.

content.text: A comment of the item in the RSS document above could be:
content.html: A comment of the item in the RSS document above could be:

content.code_html: <comments>https://www.w3schools.com/comments</comments>

content.text: The <enclosure> Element
The <enclosure> child element allows a media-file to be included with an item.
content.html: The <enclosure> child element allows a media-file to be included with an item.

content.text: The <enclosure> element has three required attributes:
content.html: The <enclosure> element has three required attributes:

content.text: A media-file included in the item in the RSS document above could be:
content.html: A media-file included in the item in the RSS document above could be:

content.code_html:
<enclosure url="https://www.w3schools.com/xml/rss.mp3"
length="5000" type="audio/mpeg" />

content.text: Get Your RSS Feed Up On The Web
Having an RSS document is not useful if other people cannot reach it.
content.html: Having an RSS document is not useful if other people cannot reach it.

content.text: Now it's time to get your RSS file up on the web. Here are the steps:
content.html: Now it's time to get your RSS file up on the web. Here are the steps:

content.text: 1. Name your RSS file. Notice that the file must have an .xml extension.
content.html: 1. Name your RSS file. Notice that the file must have an .xml extension.

content.text: 2. Validate your RSS file
content.html: 2. Validate your RSS file

content.text: 3. Upload the RSS file to your web directory on your web server.
content.html: 3. Upload the RSS file to your web directory on your web server.

content.text: 4. Copy the little orange or button to your web directory.
content.html: 4. Copy the little orange or button to your web directory.

content.text: 5. Put the little orange "RSS" or "XML" button on the page where you will offer RSS to the world (e.g. on your home page). Then add a link to the button that links to the RSS file. The code will look something like this: .
content.html:
5. Put the little orange "RSS" or "XML" button on the page where you will offer RSS to the world (e.g. on your home page). Then add a link to the button that links to the RSS file. The code will look something like this:
<a href="https://www.w3schools.com/xml/myfirstrss.xml">
<img src="https://www.w3schools.com/xml/pic_rss.gif" width="36" height="14">
</a>.

content.text: 6. Submit your RSS feed to the RSS Feed Directories (you can Google or Yahoo for "RSS Feed Directories"). Note! The URL to your feed is not your home page, it is the URL to your feed, like "https://www.w3schools.com/xml/myfirstrss.xml".
content.html: 6. Submit your RSS feed to the RSS Feed Directories (you can Google or Yahoo for "RSS Feed Directories"). Note! The URL to your feed is not your home page, it is the URL to your feed, like "https://www.w3schools.com/xml/myfirstrss.xml".

content.text: 7. Register your feed with the major search engines:
content.html: 7. Register your feed with the major search engines:

content.text: 8. Update your feed - After registering your RSS feed, you must make sure that you update your content frequently and that your RSS feed is constantly available.
content.html: 8. Update your feed - After registering your RSS feed, you must make sure that you update your content frequently and that your RSS feed is constantly available.

content.text: Can I Manage my RSS Feed Myself?
The best way to ensure your RSS feed works the way you want, is to manage it yourself.
content.html: The best way to ensure your RSS feed works the way you want, is to manage it yourself.

content.text: However, this can be very time consuming, especially for pages with lot of updates.
content.html: However, this can be very time consuming, especially for pages with lot of updates.

content.text: An alternative is to use a third-party automated RSS.
content.html: An alternative is to use a third-party automated RSS.

content.text: Automated RSS
For users who only need an RSS feed for their personal website, some of the most popular blog (Web Log) managers that offer built-in RSS services are:
content.html: For users who only need an RSS feed for their personal website, some of the most popular blog (Web Log) managers that offer built-in RSS services are:

content.text: RSS Readers
An RSS Reader is used to read RSS Feeds!
content.html: An RSS Reader is used to read RSS Feeds!

content.text: RSS readers are available for many different devices and OS.
content.html: RSS readers are available for many different devices and OS.

content.text: There are a lot of different RSS readers. Some work as web services, and some are limited to windows (or Mac, PDA or UNIX):
content.html: There are a lot of different RSS readers. Some work as web services, and some are limited to windows (or Mac, PDA or UNIX):

content.text: Tip: Most browsers have a built-in RSS Reader. If you go to a web site that offers RSS feeds, you will see an RSS icon in the address bar, or toolbar. Click on the icon to view a list of the different feeds. Choose the feed you want to read.
content.html: Tip: Most browsers have a built-in RSS Reader. If you go to a web site that offers RSS feeds, you will see an RSS icon in the address bar, or toolbar. Click on the icon to view a list of the different feeds. Choose the feed you want to read.

content.text: I have an RSS Reader. Now what?
Click on the little or button next to the RSS feed you want to read. Copy The URL you get in the browser window and paste it in your RSS reader.
content.html: Click on the little or button next to the RSS feed you want to read. Copy The URL you get in the browser window and paste it in your RSS reader.

content.text: RSS Reference
The <channel> Element
The links in the "Element" column point to more information about each specific element.
content.html: The links in the "Element" column point to more information about each specific element.

content.code_html:
Element Description
<category> Optional. Defines one or more categories for the feed
<cloud> Optional. Register processes to be notified immediately of updates of the feed
<copyright> Optional. Notifies about copyrighted material
<description> Required. Describes the channel
<docs> Optional. Specifies a URL to the documentation of the format used in the feed
<generator> Optional. Specifies the program used to generate the feed
<image> Optional. Allows an image to be displayed when aggregators present a feed
<language> Optional. Specifies the language the feed is written in
<lastBuildDate> Optional. Defines the last-modified date of the content of the feed
<link> Required. Defines the hyperlink to the channel
<managingEditor> Optional. Defines the e-mail address to the editor of the content of the feed
<pubDate> Optional. Defines the last publication date for the content of the feed
<rating> Optional. The PICS rating of the feed
<skipDays> Optional. Specifies the days where aggregators should skip updating the feed
<skipHours> Optional. Specifies the hours where aggregators should skip updating the feed
<textInput> Optional. Specifies a text input field that should be displayed with the feed
<title> Required. Defines the title of the channel
<ttl> Optional. Specifies the number of minutes the feed can stay cached before refreshing it from the source
<webMaster> Optional. Defines the e-mail address to the webmaster of the feed

content.text: The <item> Element

content.code_html:
Element Description
<author> Optional. Specifies the e-mail address to the author of the item
<category> Optional. Defines one or more categories the item belongs to
<comments> Optional. Allows an item to link to comments about that item
<description> Required. Describes the item
<enclosure> Optional. Allows a media file to be included with the item
<guid> Optional. Defines a unique identifier for the item
<link> Required. Defines the hyperlink to the item
<pubDate> Optional. Defines the last-publication date for the item
<source> Optional. Specifies a third-party source for the item
<title> Required. Defines the title of the item
